reasoning:
First things first: Alphabet (GOOG) lives in an arena I don’t claim to fully understand – the ad-tech world of search auctions, algorithms and regulators. That puts it outside my primary circle of competence. We’d rather forgo great opportunities than risk capital in areas we can’t see clearly.

Moat: On paper Google’s got a formidable network effect: the more people search, the more advertisers bid, and vice versa. That’s a durable advantage – akin to a toll bridge that collects a fee every time a car crosses. But it isn’t a moat I fully appreciate from the inside, and regulators are circling, which can erode any advantage over time.

Management: Sundar Pichai and his team have steered high returns and kept the engine humming, but we lack detailed insight into how they think about allocating excess cash. I’ve seen far more transparent capital-allocators at work in businesses I understand – think See’s Candies or GEICO.

Financial health: From public snippets we know Alphabet boasts a fortress-like balance sheet and consistent cash flow. That’s one box checked, but it’s not enough for me to leap in when I can’t value the future with any degree of certainty.

Valuation: With ‘insufficient data for reliable valuation,’ I’m flying blind. Intrinsic value is the bedrock of our process – “price is what you pay, value is what you get.” Without a sound calculation, there’s no margin of safety.

Long-term prospects and red flags: Search and ads will likely generate cash for years, but the pace of technological change and antitrust scrutiny are tangible headwinds. I’d rather sleep at night knowing I own businesses that trade less on pattern recognition and more on simple economics.

Relative to what’s in our barnyard today – Coca-Cola, Apple (which we view as a consumer products play), BNSF, and our insurance franchises – Google doesn’t measure up in terms of clarity or comfort. In sum, it’s a well-run business, but not one I’d commit Berkshire capital to when I can’t wrap my arms around the model or the value.

So I’ll sit this one out and wait for an opportunity in my wheelhouse.

moat_analysis.details: Insufficient data for comprehensive moat analysis

pricing_power_analysis.details: Insufficient data for pricing power analysis
